properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snowfall expected today. Total snowfall: near 10 cm, with higher amounts possible inland and over higher terrain. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly up to 80 km/h, stronger in the Wreckhouse area. Locations: Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity to Connaigre. Time span: midday today until this evening. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across southwestern Newfoundland today before changing to rain or drizzle this evening. Strong winds will cause a brief period of blowing snow and reduced visibility in some locations near midday. Conditions will improve this evening as rain tapers to drizzle and flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-24T06:22:21-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T14:23:21-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2880803295.2021
Area: Connaigre, Burgeo - Ramea, Channel-Port aux Basques and vicinity
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Wednesday. What: Snow, heavy at times. Total amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by Wednesday evening. Where: Greater Sudbury, North Bay, Manitoulin Island, and Killarney. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 17 -Highway 69 -Highway 11 -Highway 6 When: Wednesday morning and afternoon. The heaviest snowfall is expected from about 10:00 A.M. to 2:00 P.M. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: A potent Alberta Clipper will track across central Lake Huron on Wednesday bringing heavy snow and accumulations of 10-15 cm. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions, and impact travel on Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T12:09:05-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T20:10:05-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2544530728.2021
Area: Greater Sudbury and vicinity, West Nipissing - French River, North Bay - Powassan - Mattawa, Espanola - Killarney, Manitoulin Island
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for Wednesday. What: Snow, heavy at times. Total amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by late Wednesday evening. Where: Regions along the northeastern shore of Georgian Bay east through Algonquin to the Ottawa River. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 69 -Highway 400 -Highway 11 -Highway 17 When: Snow will begin Wednesday morning and continue until Wednesday evening. The heaviest snowfall is expected during the day on Wednesday. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: A potent Alberta Clipper will track across central Lake Huron on Wednesday bringing heavy snow and accumulations of 10-15 cm. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions, and impact travel on Wednesday. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T12:16:02-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T20:17:02-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1310038736.2021
Area: South River - Burk's Falls, Bayfield Inlet - Dunchurch, Deep River - Whitney - Eastern Algonquin Park, Western Algonquin Park - Lake of Two Rivers, Huntsville - Baysville, Town of Parry Sound - Rosseau - Killbear Park, Oxtongue Lake - Fort Irwin - Northern Haliburton County, Petawawa - Pembroke - Cobden, Barry's Bay - Killaloe
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Weather Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Winter Weather Travel Advisory in effect for overnight and Wednesday morning. What: Snow, heavy at times. Total amounts of 10 to 15 cm are expected by midday Wednesday. Where: Southern portions of Algoma District including Sault Ste. Marie and Elliot Lake. This includes sections of the following highways: -Highway 17 -Highway 129 -Highway 108 When: Overnight tonight through Wednesday morning. The heaviest snowfall is expected from about 6:00 A.M. to 10:00 A.M. Actions: Motorists should allow extra time to reach their destination. If visibility is reduced while driving, slow down, watch for tail lights ahead and be prepared to stop. Discussion: A potent Alberta Clipper will track across central Lake Huron on Wednesday bringing heavy snow and accumulations of 10-15 cm. Accumulating snow will cause poor driving conditions, and impact the commute Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to ONstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #ONStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T12:08:33-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T20:09:33-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.3206614626.2021
Area: Sault Ste. Marie - St. Joseph Island, Elliot Lake - Ranger Lake, Blind River - Thessalon
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Wind Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Strong winds that may cause damage are expected. On Wednesday, an intense weather system will generate strong southeast winds across the north and central coasts. The southeast winds will peak at speeds of 80 to 100 km/h across Haida Gwaii Wednesday afternoon followed by the north and central coasts Wednesday evening. After the system passes through, the southeast winds will shift to west winds with gusts up to 70 km/h. ### Wind warnings are issued when there is a significant risk of damaging winds. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to BCstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #BCStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T16:48:26-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-24T00:49:26-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2881146678.2021
Area: Haida Gwaii, Central Coast - coastal sections, North Coast - coastal sections
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow, rain, and strong winds are expected, especially during the evening commute. Total snowfall: 5 to 10 cm. Total rainfall: near 5 mm, except potentially more than 10 mm over the southern Avalon and Burin Peninsulas. Maximum wind gusts: southeasterly up to 80 km/h. Locations: eastern and southeastern Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon until overnight tonight. Remarks: Snow will spread across the region this afternoon before changing over to rain in the evening. Strong southeasterly winds will also develop late this afternoon, with the highest gusts expected along the coast in the evening. Conditions will improve tonight as rain tapers to drizzle and flurries. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-24T05:59:52-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T14:23:52-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.0300296329.2021
Area: Avalon Peninsula North, Avalon Peninsula Southeast, St. John's and vicinity, Avalon Peninsula Southwest, Burin Peninsula, Bonavista Peninsula, Clarenville and vicinity, Terra Nova
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Special Weather Statement In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Snow is expected. Total snowfall: 10 to 15 cm, with locally higher amounts possible. Locations: central and northeastern Newfoundland. Time span: this afternoon to near midday on Wednesday. Remarks: Snow is expected to spread across central and northeastern Newfoundland this afternoon. Winds will strengthen tonight causing blowing snow and reduced visibility, mainly over exposed areas. In the northeast, snow will taper to freezing drizzle or briefly to rain and drizzle tonight before changing back to snow Wednesday morning. Over central areas, snow will continue into Wednesday morning with further, but minor, accumulations. Snow will taper off over all areas by Wednesday afternoon. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NLstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NLwx.
Expires: 2021-02-24T06:21:51-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T14:22:51-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.4276866124.2021
Area: Deer Lake - Humber Valley, Buchans and the interior, Grand Falls-Windsor and vicinity, Bay of Exploits, Bonavista North, Gander and vicinity, Green Bay - White Bay
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Sasktel Planned Service Outage In Biggar, Asquith, Perdue
properties.Summary:
Description: On February 24th from 12:00 am (midnight) until 6:00 am SaskTel crews will be performing maintenance on the network infrastructure serving the Biggar, Asquith and Perdue area. During that timeframe, SaskTel Internet, Wireless, and Landline (SaskTel Home and Business Phone) services will be unavailable.
Expires: 2021-02-24T10:00:00-06:00
Originated from CAP Alert: SK SaskTel, 2021-02-23T09:00:34-06:00, 5B5EB5F8-09B8-2B84-556A-A5E715D6C134
Area: Biggar, Asquith, Perdue
properties.Author: SK SaskTel

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Extreme wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 65 will return tonight. These extreme wind chill values will persist through to the end of the week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T12:17:49-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T20:18:49-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1686715212.2021
Area: Cambridge Bay, Taloyoak, Gjoa Haven, Kugaaruk
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Smog Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: High concentrations of fine particulates are expected and will result in poor air quality. High concentrations of pollutants are expected to continue until tomorrow morning. ### Smog especially affects asthmatic children and people with respiratory ailments or heart disease. It is therefore recommended that these individuals avoid intense physical activity outdoors until the smog warning is lifted. Additional information: To learn more about the Info-Smog program, go to Environment Canada’s website at www.canada.ca/info-smog-program. For air quality indexes in Quebec, visit the website of the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques at www.iqa.environnement.gouv.qc.ca/contenu/index_en.asp. For the air quality index in Montréal, visit the Réseau de surveillance de la qualité de l’air de la Ville de Montréal’s website at www.rsqa.qc.ca (french only). To learn more about the effects of smog on your health in Québec, visit the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux’s website at www.quebec.ca/en/health. You can also visit the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal at www.santemontreal.qc.ca/en/public. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada.
Expires: 2021-02-24T17:27:55-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal, 2021-02-24T01:29:55-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1747114968.2021
Area: Louiseville area, Matawin - Mauricie National Park area, Lac-aux-Sables area, Shawinigan area, Sainte-Anne-de-la-Pérade area, Trois-Rivières area, Portneuf area, Valcartier - Stoneham area, Québec area, Côte-de-Beaupré - L'Île d'Orléans area, Bellechasse area, Lévis area, Saint-Lambert area, Lotbinière area, Lac-Etchemin area, Sainte-Marie-de-Beauce area, Saint-Georges-de-Beauce area, Montmagny - Saint-Jean-Port-Joli area, Saint-Fabien - Saint-Pamphile area
properties.Author: Environment Canada, the Ministère de l'Environnement et de la Lutte contre les changements climatiques, the Ministère de la Santé et des Services sociaux, the Direction régionale de santé publique du CIUSSS du Centre-Sud-de-l’Île-de-Montréal, the City of Montréal

properties.Title: Blowing Snow Advisory In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Poor visibility in snow and blowing snow is expected or occurring in some locations. A ridge of high pressure over NWT combined with a low pressure system in the Gulf of Alaska will generate strong easterly winds near the Richardson Mountains late Wednesday into Thursday. These winds will give reduced visibilities in blowing snow. ### Travel is expected to be hazardous due to reduced visibility. Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to YTstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #YTStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T15:09:45-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T23:10:45-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.1154639748.2021
Area: Dempster
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Title: Blizzard Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: Blizzard conditions with poor visibility in snow and blowing snow are expected or occurring. Strong northwesterly winds gusting to 70 km/h combined with falling snow will bring near-zero visibilities in blowing snow tonight to Sanirajak. Blizzard conditions are expected to develop this evening and end Wednesday morning. ### Please continue to monitor alerts and forecasts issued by Environment Canada. To report severe weather, send an email to NUstorm@canada.ca or tweet reports using #NUStorm.
Expires: 2021-02-24T12:39:03-00:00
Originated from CAP Alert: Environment Canada, 2021-02-23T20:40:03-00:00, urn:oid:2.49.0.1.124.2327338132.2021
Area: Sanirajak
properties.Author: Environment Canada

properties.Summary:

properties.Title: Extreme Cold Warning In Effect
properties.Summary:
Description: A multi-day episode of very cold wind chills is expected. Extreme cold wind chill values between minus 55 and minus 60 are expected this morning. While temperatures will moderate somewhat during the day, these extreme cold wind chill values may persist through to the end of the week. ### Extreme cold puts everyone at risk. Extreme cold warnings are issued when very cold temperatures or wind chill creates an elevated risk to health such as frost bite and hypothermia.
